text: live gunfire and pitched battles in
downtown Caracas
since these classes began dozens of
people have been killed with the world's
largest proven oil reserves Venezuela
should be a prosperous developed nation
but the petrol now fuels Molotov
cocktails this is now what is happening
virtually every night here in the
capital caracas and in virtually every
other city across venezuela running
battles in the streets between the
heavily armed government troops and
their opponents running down the alley
ways it's been going on like this for
about two months and it's affecting the
lives of everybody here in the capital
by day reasons for the unrest become
apparent inflation rates of fifty
percent and economic mismanagement in
huge queues for basic goods we're not
letting up buying us hey I've queued
hours for milk flour and bread but
there's no sugar says this man shortages
and an estimated twenty-five thousand
violent deaths last year means fear and
uncertainty is an everyday reality for
many Venezuelans this isn't the
socialist utopia dreamed of by former
president who go Chavez charismatic and
loved by the poor he spent billions of
Venezuela's oil revenues on social
programs Elizabeth Torres tends the
shrine to shadows even delivering his
daily cup of coffee let me see only
means SEO he created housing projects
food programs and much more she says
Chavez is still revered here but what
remains is a country divided by class
and ideology
in the western city of San Cristobal
they're clearing the barricades this is
where the uprising began student
protests against rising crime brutally
crushed by the army the military's back
in control but the cost for some has
been high we won't get away in that
one'll indycar men gan solace holds the
blood-stained glasses her son Jimmy was
wearing when he died she insists he was
shot by the army while protesting on the
streets the government says his death
was an accident they don't know get over
here and I think though she told me he
loved his country but couldn't live in a
dictatorship and felt he had to do
something about it the government will
pay for what they did to my son across
the barricades hardliners on both sides
are wary about initial peace talks
there's simply too much mistrust a
democratically elected government which
says it has the right to pursue its
agenda saponin petrol bombs at the ready
still prepared for the fight what a
Davis BBC news Caracas
